abstract.p: This article uses both data envelopment analysis (DEA) and stochastic frontier analysis (SFA) to analyze the efficiency of Japan’s major hotel companies between 2004 and 2008. This model includes four inputs and one output. DEA shows that more than half of these hotels use increasing returns to scale technologies and that they can become more efficient by enlarging their businesses. SFA efficiency scores are consistent with the DEA results. Finally, censored (Tobit) regressions are applied to investigate the determinants of the inefficiency of Japanese hotel companies. The results from DEA and SFA are consistent: being listed on the stock market has significant, positive effects on Japanese hotel efficiencies while the distance from an international airport has significant, negative effects on Japanese hotel efficiencies.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: This paper aims to analyze the efficiency of Japan’s major hotel companies using the data envelopment analysis (DEA) and stochastic frontier analysis (SFA) method. Furthermore, we investigated the determinants of hotel inefficiency using a censored (Tobit) regression. Our empirical results may shed light on the efficiency of major Japanese hotels.

In general, the tourism industry contributes to economic growth and job creation, even in industrialized countries such as Japan. The direct economic effect of domestic travel consumption on the Japanese economy was 23.5 trillion yen (2.3% of Japan’s GDP, approximately US$200 billion) in FY2007 (White Paper on Tourism in Japan, 2009). The tourism industry thus contributed 11.8 trillion yen in direct added value and 2.11 million jobs to the economy. Furthermore, its production diffusion effect was 28.5 trillion yen (i.e. 5.5% of the GDP, approximately US$451 billion), and its employment effect created 4.42 million jobs (or 6.9% of employment). Therefore, the Japanese government views promoting tourism to be an important national goal in the 21st century. In 2003, the Japanese government started the ‘Visit Japan Campaign’, which aimed to increase the number of foreign tourists to ten million per year. As a result of this campaign, the number of foreign tourists in Japan increased from 5,212,000 in 2003 to 8,351,000 in 2008. (Note that the number of foreign tourists suddenly dropped down to 6,790,000 in 2009 because of the global depression after the fall of the Lehman Brothers firm and the spread of the H1N1 influenza pandemic.)

Over the past few decades, the business environment has changed in Japan. First, leisure and official trips have decreased because of the economic depression, and hotel operation rates therefore have declined. Second, the number of hotels in Japan increased from 5,374 in 1990 to 9,603 in 2009, but the number of traditional Japanese inns decreased from 75,952 in 1990 to 50,846 in 2009. Third, the Japanese government has promoted programs such as the Visit Japan Campaign to revitalize tourism and increase the influx of foreign tourists. Fourth, many foreign luxury hotels have entered Japan’s hotel market since the 1990s. As stated above, the environment surrounding Japanese hotels is rapidly changing. However, to the best of our knowledge, no study has used DEA or any other efficiency measurement method, such as SFA, to evaluate Japanese hotel efficiency.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In the next section, we present a brief literature review on hotel efficiency studies. Then, we present our methodology and data. Subsequently, we present our empirical results. Finally, we end the paper with concluding remarks.

sec.title: Literature review
sec.p: The operating efficiency of a hotel is a crucial factor to determine its competitiveness in the hospitality industry. In general, two methods, DEA and SFA, have been used to evaluate efficiency.

DEA is widely used to evaluate the performance of decision-making units (DMUs) such as firms, governments, agencies, hospitals, and schools. It is a nonparametric, linear programming method that was introduced by Charnes et al. (1978). DEA has been used in many research fields (Charnes et al., 1994; Cooper et al., 2000; Gattoufi et al., 2004; Seiford, 1997).
The literature on hotel efficiency has grown rapidly over the past decade.

Table 1 presents a literature survey of the frontier models to measure hotel efficiency. The DEA model of hotel efficiency studies typically includes the number of employees and number of rooms as input variables (Anderson et al., 1999a, 2000; Assaf et al., 2010; Barros, 2005; Chen et al., 2010; Hu et al., 2009; Hwang and Chang, 2003; Yang and Lu, 2006). Some studies do not include physical units, but instead include monetary units as inputs, i.e. they do not include the number of employees, but instead include salaries (Anderson et al., 1999a, 1999b; Assaf and Agbola, 2011; Morey and Dittman, 1995; Reynolds, 2003;). Most studies adopt total revenue (Anderson et al., 2000; Assaf et al., 2010; Morey and Dittman, 1995; Reynolds, 2003; Yang and Lu, 2006) or disaggregated revenues in each division (Assaf and Agbola, 2011; Assaf et al., 2010; Chiang et al., 2006; Hu et al., 2009; Hwang and Chang, 2003; Tsur, 2001) as output variables. Few authors use unique variables as outputs. Brown and Ragsdale (2002) adopt customer satisfaction and value as outputs to evaluate the efficiency of hotel brands. Chiang et al. The two-stage approach in which calculated DEA efficiency scores are regressed on environmental variables using the Tobit censored model provides insight regarding the sources of inefficiency. For example, Hu et al. (2009) show that chain systems, non-metropolitan areas, and occupancy rates have significant, positive impacts on hotel efficiency. Chen et al. (2010) also show that the numbers of overseas Chinese and European tourists have significant, negative effects on cost efficiency, but that the number of Taiwanese nationals and North American, Japanese, and Australian tourists have significant, positive effects.

Recently, some studies in the literature have used SFA to investigate the efficiencies of hotels and travel management departments (Anderson et al., 1999a, 1999b; Barros, 2004, 2006; Barros and Santos, 2006; Chen, 2007; Chen and Soo, 2007; Hu et al., 2010; Rodriguez and Gonzalez, 2007). SFA is as sophisticated an approach as DEA for evaluating technical efficiency. Anderson et al. (1999b) is exceptional in that it compares the results of both DEA and SFA in one paper. Barros (2006) estimates Portuguese hotel efficiency by using SFA and then decomposes those efficiency scores into pure technical progress, nonneutral technical progress, and scale-augmenting technical progress.

The advantages and disadvantages of both methods are well known. DEA allows us to treat multiple inputs and outputs and does not require any functional form. As DEA is a deterministic approach, however, its efficiency values suffer from measurement errors and data noise. On the other hand, SFA allows us to separate random noise from efficiency levels, but it requires a specific functional form and a large sample. As Table 1 shows, most previous studies for hotel efficiency measurement apply either DEA or SFA. Therefore, we adopt both DEA and SFA to measure hotel efficiency. Considering the advantages and disadvantages of both methods, a comparison of the results of DEA and SFA is useful to measure efficiency accurately.

sec.title: DEA methodology
sec.p: DEA uses linear programming methods to construct a frontier. It uses decision-making units (DMUs) from the same period and measures their efficiencies in relation to the estimated frontier. The concept of a frontier production function, which was proposed by Farrell (1957), can account for multiple inputs. Since Charnes et al. (1978) proposed a model that assumes constant returns to scale (CRS), DEA methodology has been widely applied in various fields (Seiford and Thrall, 1990).

We assumed that we have data on K inputs and M outputs for each of N given hotels. For the i-th hotel, these data are represented by the column vectors xi and yi. The K × N input matrix X and the M × N output matrix Y represent the data for all N hotels. The input-oriented CRS DEA model solves the following linear programming problem for firm i in each year as follows: (1)minθ,λθ,s.t.-yi+Yλ≥0,θxi-Xλ≥0,λ≥0, where θ is scalar, and λ is an N × 1 vector of constants. We used the value θ as the efficiency score for the i-th hotel, which satisfies 0 ≤ θ ≤ 1. The value of unity implies a point on the frontier and thus indicates a technically efficient hotel.

Banker et al. (1984) suggested an extension of the CRS DEA model, known as the BCC model, to address situations that involve variable returns to scale (VRS). Not all hotels operate at an optimal scale, and we can therefore decompose overall technical efficiency (OTE) into pure technical efficiency (PTE) multiplied by scale efficiency (SE). In the VRS model, we can create one differentiation from CRS by adding the convexity constraint N1’λ = 1 to equation (1). N1 is an N × 1 vector of ones. Moreover, the relationship between the OTE, PTE, and SE scores is: (2)OTE=PTE×SE

sec.title: SFA methodology
sec.p: This study applies the model of Battese and Coelli (1992) to measure technical efficiency. The computer program Frontier 4.1 by Coelli (1996) is used to estimate technical efficiency levels. The production function is specified as the Cobb–Douglas production function. Therefore, the SFA model can be written as: (3)lnyit=lnxitα″+Vit-Uit, i=1,…,N,t=1,…T where α is an (N + 1) × 1 vector of coefficients; Vit follows i.i.d. normal distribution, representing the statistical noise; and Uit is a nonnegative stochastic disturbance, representing the inefficiency level. The technical efficiency scores of hotel i in time t is hence: (4)θit=E[exp(-uit)|xit], i=1,…,N,t=1,…T
Note that the efficiency scores obtained by SFA are also between 0 and 1.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: This analysis focuses on the major hotel companies in Japan for which data were available. Not all Japanese hotel companies are listed on the stock market, and it is difficult to obtain financial and management information on unlisted companies.

We constructed our database from the following two data sources. First, we mainly obtained hotel data from the Electronic Disclosure for Investors’ NETwork (EDINET), which is provided by Financial Service Agency, Japan (2010). EDINET is an official electronic corporate disclosure system in Japan. It was established by the Financial Instruments and Exchange Act, which aims to regulate broker dealers and to obligate public companies to disclose financial information. EDINET is the most reliable financial database in Japan. All listed or major companies are required to file their disclosure documents in the system. However, these data are incomplete because some hotel companies stopped disclosing information to EDINET, collapsed, closed for renovation, or were bought out by other companies between 2004 and 2008.1 Second, we compensated for some of the information that is missing from EDINET (e.g. number of seats in restaurants and bars and the number of guest rooms) by using Weekly Hotel and Restaurant (each year), which is one of the major business magazines on Japan’s hotel industry. We did not consolidate accounting data for the hotel companies to address data availability, with one exception. We did consolidate the data on Hotel Okura because its hotels are operated by subsidiary companies. As far as we know, our study made use of all available data for Japan’s hotel industry.

Our sample is smaller than those of previous studies because of data availability constraints. However, unlike SFA regressions, the DEA model does not require a large sample.2 Our DEA approach is therefore a suitable method to analyze the Japanese hotel industry. However, with 67 observations, we can still implement the SFA estimation with a sufficiently high degree of freedom.

Our study employs one output: real revenue (in 2000 price). It employs four inputs: the number of employees, the number of temporary staff, the number of seats in restaurants and bars, and the number of guest rooms. To save labor costs, hotels generally employ temporary staffers who earn lower wages than employees, and we therefore distinguished between employees and temporary staff. Combining our inputs and output variables meets the DEA convention that the minimum number of DMUs must be greater than three times the number of inputs plus outputs suggested by Raab and Lichty (2002). Our study is restricted by data availability regarding both the number of the hotels and the number of inputs and outputs. This paper, as one the first efforts to evaluate Japanese hotel efficiency, has exhausted the available data applying both the DEA and SFA techniques.

The results satisfied the isotonicity property requiring that an output should not decrease when an input increases because all of the correlation coefficients between the inputs and output were positive. sec.title: DEA efficiency results
sec.p: The average OTE score in the sample was 0.803, which indicates that the hotels could cut 19.7% of their inputs without reducing their outputs. Although the three mean efficiency scores decreased in 2004/2005, they improved in 2006/2007 and 2007/2008. The average scores for PTE and SE were 0.911 and 0.886, respectively, and the SE scores were slightly lower than the PTE scores each year. We found that scale inefficiency has a slightly larger effect on overall technical inefficiency than does pure technical inefficiency. This finding suggests that hotel managers should pay attention to the scale of operations in their hotels.

Table 5 shows that three-scale efficient hotels operated at constant returns to scale (CRS) in 2006 and 2008 and that four hotels did so for the other years. Shares of hotels operating at CRS were stable and ranged from almost 20% to 30%. We can conclude that hotels operating with CRS technology had suitable business scales. In 2004, 57.1% of the studied Japanese hotels enjoyed economies of scale and operated at increasing returns to scale (IRS). This value peaked at 78.6% in 2006 but dropped to 58.3% in 2008. More than half of the sampled hotels operated at economies of scale and at IRS. Five of the 15 hotels not only had unity PTE scores throughout the sample period but also had SE scores of less than one. This result suggests that these five hotels could become more efficient by scaling up their operations. However, because many of these hotels operate in one city, their businesses are geographically constrained. The proportion of hotels that suffered from diseconomies of scale were 14.3% in 2004, 6.7% in 2005, 0% in 2006 and 2007, and 16.7% in 2008. A few of the hotels, which were relatively large companies, operated at decreasing returns to scale (DRS) for 1 or 2 years at most. Table 5.

As shown in Table 4, we divided the studied Japanese hotels into two groups. Group A is composed of companies that operate hotels in several cities in Japan. In particular, the Hotel Okura, the Imperial Hotel, and the New Otani are known as ‘Japan’s big three hotels’, and each of them has a long history and is a strong brand. In contrast, Group B is composed of companies that operate one hotel in one city. Four hotel companies in Group B operate in large cities with populations of more than one million people: the Marunouchi Hotel in Tokyo, the Hotel Newgrand in Yokohama, the Nagoya Kanko Hotel in Nagoya, and the Kyoto Hotel in Kyoto. The rest of the hotels in Group B are located in cities with populations of less than one million people.

For each year of the sample period, the average OTE and SE scores of the hotels in Group A were larger than those in Group B, but the average PTE scores of the Group B hotels were larger than those of the Group A hotels. This finding suggests that the hotels in Group A enjoy SE and that the hotels in Group B suffer from scale inefficiency. Since OTE = PTE × SE, we can attribute the Group B hotels’ low average OTE scores to their low SE scores.

Here, we consider the performance of the individual hotels. The hotels with average OTE scores above 0.9 were the Hotel Okura, the Imperial Hotel, the JAL Hotels, and the Hotel New Otani Takaoka. The Imperial Hotel demonstrated the ‘best practice’ among the studied Japanese hotels and had the highest OTE ranking with a unity OTE score throughout the sample period. This finding is not surprising because the Imperial Hotel is one of the oldest hotels in Japan, and thus, it can set high accommodation and other prices because of its brand value. The five hotels with an average OTE index value of less than 0.7 were the Hotel New Akao, the Nagasaki Grand Hotel, the Kumamoto Hotel, the Palace Hotel, and the Gunma Royal Hotel. With the exception of the Palace Hotel, these hotels are in Group B and operate in cities with populations of less than one million inhabitants. For most of the sample period, the four hotels had SE index values that were lower than their PTE index values. This finding implies that the hotels might be at a competitive disadvantage because they operate in small cities.

Next, we consider the cases of two companies. First, JAL Hotels improved its efficiency from 0.887 on the OTE score in 2004 to 1.000 in 2006, and the company has maintained its unity score since then. Conventionally, however, JAL Hotels has been associated with the poor management of its parent company, the Japan Airlines Corporation, which went bankrupt in January 2010. In the 2000s, JAL Hotels scaled down its operations to improve its management. It changed its business structure from hotel ownership to hotel operations and cut down its interest-bearing debt. JAL Hotels transferred its three direct management hotels to other companies between 2005 and 2007 and subsequently operated them as a trustee. Moreover, JAL Hotels closed two hotels in 2007 and 2008. Thus, the company drastically downsized its operations. Its real revenue shrank 29.8% between 2004 and 2008, and its number of employees decreased 39.7%. Likewise, its number of temporary staff shrank 10.5%, the number of seats in its restaurants and bars dropped 31.0%, and the number of guest rooms decreased 23.6%. The unity OTE scores from 2006 suggest that it was a successful business downsize. Second, we focus on the Nagasaki Grand Hotel, which went bankrupt in 2006 because of excess debt. This company is the only one in the sample that went bankrupt. The OTE of the Nagasaki Grand Hotel was very low, at 0.679 in 2004 and 0.569 in 2005. Because both of the company’s PTE values for the 2 years are unity, we can attribute its overall technical inefficiency to scale inefficiency.

sec.title: SFA efficiency results
sec.p:
Table 6 summarizes the estimation results on SFA model. The coefficient of the number of employees is significant at 1%, and the coefficients of the number of seats and rooms are significant at 5%. Only the coefficient of the number of temporary staff is not significant and negative. The frontier parameters, σ2 = σ2V + σ2U, γ = σ2U/(σ2V + σ2U), μ as the truncated normal distribution parameter, and η as the time-variant inefficiency parameter, are all significant. The value of γ at 0.830 implies that a significant proportion of the total variance in the error component is used by the inefficiency effect. The value of μ at 0.402 implies the distribution of the inefficiency term is truncated normal. The value of η at 0.040 shows that Japanese hotel efficiency is improving over time. Table 7 shows the results of SFA efficiency. OTE (Table 4) and SFA efficiency (Table 7) are different, but they have similar rankings. The correlation coefficient between OTE and SFA efficiencies is 0.594 during the sample years.3 Imperial Hotel is the best performer in both the SFA model and the DEA model. Hotels that showed similar performances in both of the models are Kyoto Hotel, Kumamoto Hotel Castle, Nagasaki Grand Hotel, Nagoya Kanko Hotel, Palace Hotel, and Royal Hotel. The performances of remaining hotels vary between SFA and DEA models because of the difference in the frontiers found by these two approaches. Table 6.

sec.title: Tobit regression
sec.p:
We employed a Tobit censored regression model to investigate the determinants of the hotels’ overall technical efficiency scores as a product of PTE and SE.4 The regressions for each decomposed item, such as PTE and SE, had fewer significant coefficients. Therefore, regressions of the hotels’ overall technical efficiency scores can provide a broad picture of the efficiency score determinants. We studied six environmental variables: the type of operation (OPE; 1 = chain, 0 = independent), the type of location (LOC; 1 = resort area, 0 = metropolitan), distance to the nearest international airport (DIS), years of operation as a hotel company (HIS), quote status (QUO; 1 = quoted company, 0 = unquoted company), and fixed assets (FIX). We defined inefficiencies INOTE, INPTE, and INEFF as (1/efficiency efficiency scores)−1 with respect to OTE, PTE, and SFA and estimated it as follows: (5)Inefficiencyit=β0+β1OPEit+β2LOCit+β3DISit +β4HISit+β5QUOit+β6FIXit+ɛit where subscript i denotes a hotel company, subscript t denotes a time period, β0 is constant, and εit is the error term that follows a normal distribution. Because we limited the value of the inefficiency defined by equation (3) at zero, we used the Tobit model. Table 8 shows the results for the Tobit regression. As defined above, the dependent variable is inefficiency. Therefore, a positive coefficient implies a decrease in efficiency, and a negative coefficient implies an increase in efficiency. Table 8.

The coefficient of the distance between a hotel and its nearest international airport, β3, is significant and positive5 for all three inefficiencies. Therefore, the farther a hotel is from the nearest airport, the less efficient it is. In other words, hotels that are far from international airports are at a disadvantage. The estimated coefficient of the type of quote, β5, is significant and negative for INOTE and INTEE and is also associated with lower inefficiency. This finding suggests that listed hotels have an advantage over unlisted hotels because they can collect funds and invest in equipment to improve their management. The significant, negative coefficient for INEFF on fixed assets, β6, implies that, as might be expected, larger fixed assets contribute to efficient operations.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: Although the hotel industry is one of the most important domestic demand-oriented industries in Japan, no studies to date have investigated the efficiency of Japan’s hotels. Our empirical results provide efficiency scores for Japanese hotels between 2004 and 2008 using both DEA and SFA.

Our results show an average overall technical efficiency of 0.803 during this period, which implies that the hotels could reduce their inputs such as employment and equipment by 19.7% without reducing their revenues. More than half of the hotels operate under increasing returns to scale technology and could improve their efficiency if they enlarged their business scales. In this analysis, we divided the major Japanese hotels into two groups. The first group included hotels that operate in several cities, and the second group included those that operate in one city. The results suggest that many hotels in the first group enjoy scale efficiency and that many in the second group suffer from scale inefficiency.

The SFA efficiency results provide useful information as an alternative method and reinforce the DEA results. The correlation coefficient between OTE and SFA efficiencies is 0.594 during the sample years. Among the 15 hotels studied, Imperial Hotel is the best performer with respect to the above three types of efficiency scores. Whereas the results from DEA and SFA are similar, the remaining hotels exhibit different performance among the different models because of the basic assumptions of those models.

We also use the Tobit regression to analyze the determinants of hotel inefficiency. The results from DEA and SFA are consistent. First, hotels that are closer to international airports achieve higher efficiency. Second, a listed hotel tends to be more efficient than an unlisted hotel.

On the other hand, the correlation coefficient between PTE and SFA efficiencies is even lower, at only 0.392.

Simar and Wilson (2007) criticize regression on DEA efficiency using explanatory environmental variables because a coherent data generating process is not described in the previous studies and because DEA-estimated efficiencies are serially correlated. However, the truncated regression recommended by Simar and Wilson (2007) needs a larger sample size. Because of the limitation of the small sample size, we follow the traditional two-stage approach using the Tobit model.

Because large cities in Japan do not necessarily have nearby international airports, the causality between a large city and the distance to the nearest international airport may not be a significant ex ante factor in this regression.

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Satoshi Honma is a professor at the Kyushu Sangyo University. He specializes in the study of environmental and energy economics.

Jin-Li Hu is a professor and the director of Institute of Business and Management, National Chiao Tung University, Taiwan. He received his PhD degree in economics from State University of New York at Stony Brook. His research fields include decision science, efficiency and productivity, tourism management, and energy policy.
